title: John Lewis and Waitrose ban plastic toys in Christmas crackers
text:

Two chains are to stop selling Christmas crackers containing plastic toys and trinkets.

John Lewis and sister store Waitrose aim for a green Christmas next year in a war on plastic waste.

Cracker staples including plastic jewellery, mini-combs, and yo-yos will make way for recyclable material such as metal or card.

Next year, stencilling or embossing will replace glitter on crackers.

Glitter is made of tiny plastic pieces that can end up in the sea.

Dan Cooper, head Christmas buyer at John Lewis said: “Reducing single use plastic in products and packaging is really important to us and our customers.

“One of the challenges I face as a buyer is that we plan 18 months ahead, so it takes time for changes to become a reality.

"I’m always searching for new, more sustainable products which will make Christmas sparkle, but won’t end up spoiling our environment.”

The department store has already cut glitter by two thirds on its own brand Christmas wrapping paper, advent calendars and gift bags.

Supermarket Waitrose said from next year festive flowers and plants, own label cards, gift wrap and tags will be glitter free.

It means daft games like the classic “fortune telling” plastic fish that indicates the future by the way it curls in the palm of the hand will be consigned to the scrapheap.

The move towards plastic-free festive fun comes as more shoppers are snapping up greener “fill your own” crackers instead.

According to John Lewis figures, the DIY crackers that families fill with their own gifts now account for a third of sales at its stores.

Tesco is also switching to degradable plastic-free glitter on its festive horticulture range and removing glitter from own brand wrapping paper, tags and single Christmas cards.

Scientists and eco-campaigners estimate around eight million tonnes of plastic is currently floating in the world’s oceans, affecting 600 species.
description: Glitter and plastic toys are being phased out of Christmas crackers, wrapping paper and trinket, as department stores and supermarkets realise the environmental damage they do
